content.content: I’ve created a repository called dss-gov-rewards which houses the contracts to enable paying out rewards to MKR locked in governance. Why? Maker security relies on binding MKR holders to the consequences of their votes. This assumption is broken for MKR that is borrowed on a lending platform. We have solved the most extreme version of this with flash loans, but the underlying problem remains. Fundamentally, Maker is not secure if there is more MKR available to borrow than there is locked in Chief/DssGov. The simplest and probably most robust way to solve this is to pay people to lock their MKR in chief and thus keep their MKR off the market. Implementation dss-gov-rewards is a lightly modified rewards contract from the UNI LP pool rewards. MKR IOU tokens can be deposited in, and you get rewards out. Both the staking and rewards tokens are arbitrary, so this can be used for rewards in either DAI or MKR depending on what governance wants to do. Additionally because this is a separate module from dss-gov, it can be deployed for the current Chief as well as DssGov. I’ve also added DaiRewardsDistributor as an example of how rewards can be done via the keg module. The idea here is to siphon off some % of the MKR burn and redirect it to rewards. The nice thing about this is we can adjust that % to control for how much of a ratio we want of MKR on the market vs locked in governance. Alternatively the rewards can be made in MKR as well if the community desires. Another bonus of this module sitting completely outside governance is that we can upgrade it very easily. We simply shut off rewards to the existing contract and switch them to a new contract. IOU tokens are completely opt-in to whichever contract they want, so people will move over naturally. This may be useful in the case where DeFi liquidity pools start automatically depositing into rewards (similar to what Compound does with Dai and the DSR). Security This module is using code that has already been audited and tested in production, so it should be safe to use. Additionally, since it is sitting outside the core Maker system, and only interacts with the IOU tokens there is limited room for catastrophic bugs. Worst case scenario we can just turn off the reward stream and we burn a few days of revenue. Discussion Looking for feedback on the route governance wants to take with this. Do we want to distribute rewards in MKR or DAI? Should we divert some portion of the MKR burner into rewards (% of profit) or should we pull it as a fixed operating cost? What % of profit should be used? Should we target some ratio of MKR on the market vs locked in governance. Please note that I’m expecting for historical reasons the Foundation cannot comment or be involved with this project.

content.content: Dividends and taxes are something we should consider, but they are not the main reason behind this module. The main reason is to secure the system against having too much MKR on the market. This is a classic prisoners dilemma game theory problem where individual defectors (MKR holders who loan their MKR) are rewarded with interest on their MKR. The only way to prevent this in my view is to give them a better offer. So yes taxes are unfortunate depending on your politics, but I don’t see any other way to solve this. Keep in mind I suspect we may not need to go very high to beat the market. Aave offers 1.25% interest on MKR, so with 29M in fees / year we would only need to run the rewards at 20% of the burner to match that.

content.content: The disadvantage of rewards in DAI (coming from collected fees) is that they will be negatively correlated with MKR price/Marketcap (in % terms). E.g. to match the current 1.2x% yield on AAVE, on current 180m USD of MKR locked inside voting contract, Maker would need to spend 2.2m DAI yearly, but this 2.2m DAI will be only 0.6% yield if the MKR price doubles. As you can see, the “problem” is as MKR price will rise the rewards (in % terms) will decrease, but this doesn’t apply to money market protocols like AAVE or Compound. So if/when the MKR price increases significantly we will be back where we were, the rewards will be negligible in comparsion to interest rate offered by money market protocols. This problem doesn’t apply to rewards coming from MKR supply inflation, because as the MKR price rises (or decreases), the rewards do too (in $ terms). Both types of rewards have its pros and cons and in my opinion some % combination of both is superior to either alone. E.g. when MKR price is low: [80% burn, 20% DAI rewards], 0% MKR supply inflation/rewards, when MKR price is very high: [0% MKR burn (surplus buffer increased), 0% DAI rewards], 100% of rewards coming from MKR supply inflation (for example 1% supply inflation).

content.content: Was thinking there could be some unintended consequences here. First, stated goals are:  Reduce borrowable MKR (to prevent malicious use) Encourage voting participation (raise threshold for malicious actions)  Imagine we create this rewards contract for staking governance Maker IOU token (call it GovMKR) to earn Dai. First, some MKR holders will prefer continue maximizing MKR value (as pure MKR burning does), so if they get Dai they’ll want to reinvest it into MKR.  However, like other rewards “farming” activities, that can be laborious and expensive at small scale.  Therefore we should expect to see something like a yMKR yearn vault which fixes that problem with scale, as it does for other rewards farming, and automates re-investing in MKR. Some MKR holders will do that to maximize rewards even though it means giving up voting rights! So either the vote is effectively delegated (e.g. to YFI holders) or, the yMKR vault might be designed to just not vote at all. In the former case, the original goal of making MKR unavailable to borrow (for system security) is potentially undermined.  Depending on how the vault is designed, it might still allow a malicious user to vote with all the pooled MKR.  In the later case, it has the effect of making voting impossible, which also leaves the system less secure, since at least some MKR holders might have voted. What if the staking contract rewards in MKR instead of DAI? This might be a bit better actually. Now, the same person who wants to continue maximizing their MKR value can just deposit to the voting contract and stake their GovMKR to increase their MKR balance. Since there’s no need to harvest Dai and reinvest, there’s no need for a yMKR vault.

content.content: If we don’t want farming we just need to forbidden contract to call the staking method or introduce an allowed list on it.

You are correct in that there is nothing we can do from a technical perspective to prevent liquidity pools from putting the MKR into the rewards contract due to the permission-less nature of the blockchain. However, there are a few mechanisms we can use to keep this number low.  It takes time and effort to build a contract which pools liquidity, and inserts that liquidity into MKR rewards. We make it very clear we do not want this, and present a credible threat that we will just redeploy the contract if the liquidity on these markets becomes too liquid or possibly start using a blacklist if that ends up being easier. It’s a bit of a cat and mouse game, but I think we have the upper hand. MKR holders should be aware of the dangers of lending out their MKR. Rewards can help to reduce the chance of defection from any individual, but ultimately it’s up to them.  In any case we need a tool to combat high APYs on lending markets. The lending rates are not super high right now (~1% on Aave), but imagine if that goes up to something like 5%+. I could see a situation where the trade offs of listing your MKR on the market is too high for the individual to resist with an “everyone else is doing it, so I might as well too” mentality.

But if the assumption is that they’re being rewarded for good governance, they should probably be given the opportunity to govern more. If this continues the TVL crown may not stay with MakerDAO for much longer even if total Dai goes to new all time highs. MKR cannot continue to rest on its first-mover advantage laurels and continue using a tokenomics model that is quantifiably lagging new entrants, so I’m glad this is under discussion. content.content: While I understand that much of the code has already been written, I do want to present an alternative incentive structure that may have the same outcome but also may (subject to local tax situations which are different for everyone) be equally tax efficient as the current construct. While acknowledging the objective is to encourage voting and maintain the hat, another method instead of causing the equivalent of a dividend would setting forth an options model. The option model being that based on how long your MKR is locked in the governance contract that you (or the delegated MKR) would accrue an option to acquire MKR at a discount. This discount would be controlled by governance. Further, the notion that you have locked your MKR also would start a weighted average on the MKR strike price.  (e.g. locking in early… and locking for a long-time is the objective). Then only when the option is exercised the protocol would “mint” new MKR … and my understanding of tax law would be that the discount received would be taxable (but it was deferred). Key points on the above is that it would require some decently complex coding (though compared to DSS it “should” be easier) but it would further align interests of the DAO to reward voting… thoughts?
